Product received for free
												IntroductionI am Tigerfrost. I would like to apologize for anything that is miss-spelled or any grammar issues. Thank you.If you'd like to skip straight to Pro's & Con's, please move to the bottom of the page. Thank you.How I Found Out About "Just Cause 2"The same way I found out about a lot of games, from YouTube. I randomly came across a video that was showing someone driving a vehicle off of a tall snowy mountain. The crash and destruction effects made me fall in love. See, I've always loved destruction in games/movies/etc. So when I see something like that, I know I must own the game. Unfair First ImpressionsI've seen a lot of different unfair first impressions for this game. The first, and most simple being, the fact that someone may not have liked the original Just Cause game. Therefor it leads to an automatic thought that any sequel will be just as bad, or worse. I can understand this, but believe me, Just Cause 2 makes everything better. Second, I've heard that the game can get low reviews and less players because of it's story. I know some people are looking for games for their story. However, not everyone is. You can have a game like Just Cause 2 where the story is bad but the gameplay is good, very good. Third, because it's a third person shooter style of game. Which can turn some people away. Review Of "Just Cause 2"Just Cause 2 is a massive open world, sandbox, TPS game, that comes with a full story, side missions, bonus missions, and so many collectables that you'll die before finding all of them. The world of Just Cause 2 is massive (Panau). One of biggest I have ever seen! Stretching across desert terrain and mountains, snowy mountains and terrain, jungle and marsh, ocean, urban areas, and military bases. One downside to the world of Just Cause 2 is that it may be very big, but it's not well populated with stuff. Meaning, all that jungle and desert, 90% of it will not have anything in it besides sand and trees. So you may find the world itself being very boring at times. However, the rest of the game makes up for that. In the world of Just Cause 2, there are urban areas to explore. Villages that may hold resources and ammo to big cities that contain higher costing vehicles & helicopters. Places like airports where you can obtain a passenger jet. There are military bases you can liberate by destroying & collecting all things within it. These bases could consist of ports, vehicle factories, little infantry camps, to big fortress type places. You can get around the world of Just Cause 2 with many things. First of all, you can use your grappling hook to get to higher places, then you can use your parachute to glide down or travel across land faster. Not only is that the most basic of travel, there are vehicles...a lot. There are a little over 100 vehicles in Just Cause 2. Anything from ATV's, motorcycles, cars, trucks, boats, armored cars, planes, helicopters, etc. The list goes on. One thing that I do not care for in the vehicle department is the vehicle physics. The vehicle isn't really that responsive, or reliable. You can hit the movement key lightly and the vehicle will spin out, even at low speeds. You can defend yourself with weapons like SMG's, shotguns, etc. There really aren't many weapons to use in the default game unless you purchase DLC. However, there is still so much content in the game, you don't actually need DLC so the DLC is just there for bonus weapons & vehicles. I would like it if Just Cause 2 had more weapons in the default game. With how big the world is, having more weapons gives you more options to do things with.This isn't really the game that plays like a TPS game. You don't run up to a base and get behind cover then start attacking. The AI is kind of stupid, and the same time, they work well. There really isn't any stealth. The concept behind Just Cause 2 is that you drive in for fly in, kill everything, and walk away from a massive explosion. As for the story and side missions. The story itself is generic and not really exciting, except for the final mission. There are only six missions I believe, maybe more. However, to unlock story missions you must gain chaos which can be obtained by destroying key points in military bases, fighting the military, collecting things, or completing side missions. There are a lot of side missions to choose from three different sub factions who you'll find fighting the military at times. The side missions themselves can actually be unique and fun, however the briefing itself is low. Every mission start, you'll stand there and the leader of the sub faction will drive by, tell you what you need to do, and then drive away. Not a word said. Don't get me wrong, Just Cause 2 is a great game, it just may not be what you are looking for.Content In Just Cause 2 (Bonus Missions & Collectables)In the world of Just Cause 2, you have bonus missions alongside "side missions". These mainly consist of races, for all vehicle types. Other then that, you have thousands of collectables. These can be little pickups for the sub factions, or little resource crates that boost your stats, like giving you weapon parts to upgrade your weapons, or armor parts to give you more health, etc. To gain 100% in Just Cause 2 requires you to collect every piece of sub faction items and resources, also, destroying key military structures in an area. Each area you discover will give you a progress bar, when everything has been collected or destroyed, the progress bar will reach 100% and that area is clear. However, the PC version of Just Cause 2 experienced a bug where a few items & structures do not spawn in the game. Therefor it is impossible to beat the game 100% without a mod. The devs apparently do not care to fix this easily fixed problem. Pro's & Con's (Overall Rating)Just Cause 2 is an open world TPS that provides a wide variety of collectables and fun destruction. You can spend hours on the game before ever reaching 15% for full completion. Despite needing a mod to fully beat the game 100%. There has alos been a community mod released that allows people to play together in the world of Panau. Pro's:+Massive open world.+Loads of collectables for hours of game time.+Fun destruction system.+Addicting "I must find everything" style.+DLC is not required to play.+Nice variety of vehicles.Con's:-Mod needed for full completion.-Enemy will spam helicopters.-Mostly boring empty world. -Strange vehicle mechanics.-Low leveled main story & side mission briefing.Overall Rating: About A 12/15 (A Nice Game That's Worth A Pickup)Credits & DisclaimerThank you for taking the time to read my review, I hope this helped out with your decision on whether to make a purchase or not.Remember, this review is based off of opinion only. You may not think the same way as me towards something, but that's okay, because we are all human.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												I've played Just Cause 2 originally on xbox 360 and put more than 20+ hours into it. Panau is a big beautiful island with lots to see and as Rico AKA The Scorpio as your tour guide. Rico is a mercenary looking for someone on the island and is drafted to help local gangs reign chaos in an attempt to complete his own personal mission.Just Cause 2 follows somewhat of a GTA game play scheme. Notable differences include driving and the obvious attachment of a hook shot / grapple. This grapple is what makes Just Cause, Just Cause. This thing can literally attach to anything within a certain distance. This includes automobiles, helicopters, buildings, boats, trees, mountains and literally anything you can think of. Upon grappling onto a car, Rico can perform "stunt jumps" in which he is able to maneuver himself on and around the car. This comes handy in case you are being fired at and need some extra cover. When attaching oneself to a helicopter, Rico can chill underneath or just like a car, attempt to hijack it. There are a few QTE (quick time events) that need to be performed in order to successfully high jack any moving vehicle. You can also grapple enemies if you're really feeling it. Alternatively, Rico can attach his grapple to two objects. Say you want to shoot at an explode-able object but it's not quite close enough to the enemies. Rico can shoot his grapple at the barrel and then attach it nearby or on the enemy. Once the barrel is shot and starts flying, the grapple will pull it towards the enemy. It's an extremely cool feature but with a few flaws. If you're trying to get cars that pass by to run into it, it doesn't really work. For one reason or another the game made it so you cannot simply have people running into the grapple. What you may do though is use it against cars or helicopters. Being chased? Not a problem. Attach to the car then attach to the road or any tree that's nearby and watch them flip. Driving is sort of it's own unique thing in the game. When the car is flipping over multiple times I like how they did that effect, but I do not like how they made the driving scheme. It seems a little stiff and controls sometimes don't react as you want them to. Shooting is quite basic in the game and auto-targeting seems welcomed.You may zoom in while shooting and even dual wield certain weapons. Weapons can be swapped for different weapons and three slots are available to fill up. Smaller automatics and pistols can swapped out for one another (one slot). Bigger shotguns or automatics can be switched (second slot). The third slot consists of grenades or C4 (both which can be carried at the same time). Shooting is decently fun but can get old. You can crouch and roll to evade fire from enemies but there is no real cover system. It would have been nice if they added something like Gears of Wars has in regards to taking cover. What is notable in this game is that lots can be blown up. Sadly, it's not on a Mercenaries 2 : world in flames sort of demolition (which I think to this date is still the best) but JC2 still has it's moments. There is fun in mindless violence of blowing entire enemy bases up (from radio towers, electrical stations, gas tanks, enemy vehicles and towers). What you can do damage to is sort of limited. In Mercenaries 2 you could blow up an entire oil rig. In JC2, that oil rig has only certain aspects you can take out. Whether this is good or bad is determined by you. By pressing down on the D-pad you may call up "the sloth demon" aka your personal distributor of weapons, vehicles and extraction if needed. They really gave the player a chance to enjoy a wide variety on their menu but most unlock only after a certain amount of progress has been made (be it collecting crates, completing missions or blowing government equipment up). Anything here also costs a pretty penny!The game is known for it's beautiful graphics especially demonstrating the beauty of being able to encapsulate the entire island in the background. Even though it's not the next gen sort of graphics, it still provides for an enjoyable sight to see. The display for the weapon meters are excellently done. Even though you may run out of ammo a lot, you'll know exactly how much you have left.  Sounds are varied (explosions are finally sounding different) and comments are made by either Rico, enemies and even civilians. They organized the map in a way that is extremely easy to figure out where you are and where you want to go. They were even kind enough to indicate where potential hidden locations could be. Overall, a fantastic game. Even with a few minor flaws the gamer is sure to enjoy Just Cause 2.RATING : 7.9/10Gameplay B+ Story / Campaign B Visuals / User Interface B Sounds / Music B Replay-ability B Overall  BWould have been 8 if they fixed a few grappling issues. Not only that, if you hit a civilian full throttle in a truck they won't fall off their bike. They just bounce away in the air. Kinda weird ain't it?ScreenShots Do you like helicopters Be quick on your toes when the QTE's turn up Do you like fighter planes This is actually a lot funner than it looks Do you like commercial airliners that is on fire

It is completely free and you can do tons of cool stuff with your friends in there. Did I mention that it is free?So if you like open world games, explosions, great open world multiplayer explosions and tanks and jets and explosions...BUY THE GAME!

Posted: March 19, 2016
												A nice little timewaster for a couple of hours and then you'll never pick it up again.I'm not very familiar with this series but as a fan of the sandbox genre I was immediately hooked by the fun gameplay and appealing graphics. It's incredibly appealing to just mess around, cause havoc and experiment with the various gameplay mechanics but the initial enjoyment doesn't last long. As you start to discover the impressively sized island with various vehicles and gadgets it quickly dawns on you that the developers went for quantity over quality here. Every design element and situation is repeated ad nauseam and there is no variety to the environments which is of course due to the nature of the game world being set in a fictional asian setting (that admittedly made me want to go on vacation in thailand and cambodia again) but I have to ask myself the question why the developers didn't choose a more intriguing setting with variety. Perhaps the idea was to get away from the genre-defining GTA series; but nowadays sandbox games have generally gone far beyond GTA clones and are rightfully recognized as a genre of its own, so much so even GTA-clones as the first Saints Row develop a completely unique identity as they progress.The main problem with all the gadgets and functions in Just Cause 2 is that they are all introduced at the beginning of the game and while they are a lot of fun and give the game a unique flavour there isn't anything left to discover after the first hour or two. Surprised enjoyment followed by sobering grinding.The storyline department is also severely lacking, not that these games are usually poetic masterpieces but I can't even remember a single character, as in what is their name and character. I have no investment in short-haired action man with hookshot and thus didn't continue playing once the novelty wore off. The game is too self-aware for its own good ( not self-aware funny like Saints Row alas): nameless person in nameless setting against nameless antagonists. They have names but it never matters for a second; despite the beautiful visuals you never feel like you are traversing a real world, and even a cartoonishly over the top world can feel credible/plausible if it's internally consistent and has proper world building to draw you in. This felt more like a licensed game of one of those god-awful expendables movies.In that sense Just Cause is the epitome of a sandbox, you get nothing out of it that you don't bring yourself and you have to figure out your own way to have fun, namely smashing things together. Which is fine I guess but it comes off more like the developers couldn't be asked to do that themselves. They clearly have the skills to make all the mechanics of a sandbox game work but they don't add anything to it.If you can get this one on sale, you're gonna have fun for a little while but don't expect a memorable experience, Just Cause 2 is a distraction more than an experience.

												A just cause of 'just because'.One of the classical overly-explosive action games, this game is a great throwback to the old 80's Rambo-esque movies and mixes traditional third person destruction derby with open world (group of islands) adventure. A tropical GTA of sorts. The basic gameplay consists of destroying evil goverment's property, i.e. water and fuel supplies in random villages, races with every medium possible and both storyline and faction quests. As mentioned earlier, this game embraces the goofy righteousness and lets you wreak havoc upon both the goverment and its civilians with little difference.Technically this game is a port from original PS3 game, but from my experience it runs great. Even on my laptop I had stable performance on lower graphical settings and the game looks still fantastic for a game of its age (in my mind that's yesterday). The positive points of this game lie in it's great map design, freedom of gameplay done right (main story is there to create atmosphere and not to restrict features) and a certain kind of 'comfyness' if you're weird enough to get nostalgic about games of this era. (I could also talk about personal experiences I have when this game came out and I played a ton of it w/ my friend but buzzwords are way cooler.) I think Just Cause 2 does what it does so well that I'm probably never going to buy another game that tries to accomplish the same. (For me this is a big deal, especially since the third part of the series just came out)There aren't much negative stuff for me to say. The game has it's bugs and flaws, but for me it would be such a nitpick on stuff that didn't affect my experience. The world is so huge and detailed that finding incomplete pieces feels more like an easter egg than letdown. It does what it promises well, but for people who want a more sensible plot and structural gameplay this might be a short experience.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I almost didn't play Just Cause 2. Twice. The first time was before buying it. I hesitated because of how huge everyone made the game world seem. The impression I got was that there was more to do here than every Elder Scrolls combined. And I didn't want to make that kind of a time commitment. But when it went on sale it was too cheap to pass up.After intsalling and trying to start the game is when I almost gave up a second time. I couldn't get the game to run for more than about 5 mintues without crashing. That meant I would race desperately to get to the next checkpoint before the game crashed. I couldn't pause or explore or do anything but rush blindly ahead. Even on normal you can't do that without dying though. So I gave up for a while and played some other games, hoping for a patch or some explanation.Eventually, months later I tried again, but the game hadn't been patched and probably wasn't ever going to be. So I researched some fixes. Nothing seemed to work. The two biggest recommendations were to run in Windows 7 compatability mode and to turn off decals. Neither worked. BUT I got lucky and just decided on a whim to do both at the same time. The first time the game ran for 15 minutes without crashing I almost cried. Then I made it to an hour. More. So luckily, that combination fixed it for me. But the real shame of this game is that I almost missed it entirely because of such a horrible beginning experience and having to manually change things to get it to even run.Once it did run though, it was an awesom experience. In a word: fun. And really just plain, simple, fun. The first two tutorial-heavy story missions are actually a bad opening to the game, even though they introduce all the necessary concepts. They're too linear. Too narrow. The best part about Just Cause is how open and free and spontaneous the world is. The story missions largely lack all of that. The controls also took some getting used to. Having dodge be tab - an awkward button to hit repeatedly - and aim be C - something I've never encountered before - threw me for a while. Eventually I did get used to the controls though and I couldn't find a mapping I liked more than the default one. There's just a learning curve and you have to power through it.In the open world and used to the controls, the game shines. Largely because there is a lot to do, but you don't even have to do any of it. I spent my first 10 hours or so just exploring and causing chaos and searching for items. And it was addictive. And fun!Then I moved on to the races. I didn't expect them to be good, but with only a few exceptions (i.e. plane flights through cities and driving on snow) I found the racing to be insanely well executed. I looked forward to completing all of them and beat all 75 even though I didn't have to.The faction missions are also fun, although I realized that the shorter they were, generally the better. Just Cause seems to be meant for bite-sized play, with a short rise and fall of action. The longer missions, whether story related or not, were where the game suffered.And the story itself is terrible. The writing, voice acting, all horendous. There are as many accents as there are voice actors, and most of them don't sound like any kind of real accent at all. It's quite jarring until you get used to it. But in some ways this actually works in the game's favor, because it reminds you not to take it seriously.So if you want a third person action game akin to GTA but even bigger and less serious (though maybe a bit less absurd than something like Saints Row) Just Cause is the place to get it.

Posted: June 11, 2015
												Just Cause 2 is probably one of the most eye catching action sandboxes going; thrust into the large sandbox of Panau by parachute you are the stereotypical CIA one man wonder weapon which will tame the hostile regieme for good old uncle sam. But in honesty you do not buy Just Cause 2 for its depth, but rather for the action, the carnage, the pretty explosions, and the pleasant vistas of Panau itself. In many respects Just Cause 2 builds on the premise of Mercenaries and Mercenaries 2; joinable factions, main story missions, side missions, supply drops, vehicle drops, weapon upgrades and the ever present regieme installations, bases, airfields and towns that can be taken one at a time. Either going in solo or working for the various opposition factions does make you feel like you are toppling the regieme one satisfying step at a time. Also be pleasantly surprised by excellent frames per second on the highest of graphics settings; one of the most visually stunning yet stable platforms made for the PC.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Just Cause 2 is all you could want in an open world island adventure. You star as Rico Rodriguez, a man with the task of assassinating his former mentor who has turned crazy. Along the way you will meet several groups of revolutionary armies, such as the Reapers and the Ular Boys, who will send you on missions to hack military bases, takeover strongholds or assassinate colonels. The game is fast-paced and action packed. The main highlights of the game I found were the grappling hook and parachute. Rico is equipped with these from the get-go, and aiming at a certain spot on the ground with the grapple will send you flying off into that direction. Together with the easily deployable parachute, you hardly need cars to travel around the island of Panau.A minor downside to this game is the loading times. You will be left waiting awhile before entering the world, but is all worth it once in. One feature that is very helpful is the addition of the Black Market. Call for a chopper if you need weapons, vehicles or need to be flown to any previously discovered location (very helpful for Stronghold Takeovers). There are not an excessive amount of weapons in the game, ranging from the light and common pistol and submachine gun, to more powerful guns like shotguns and detached mounted guns (with insanely helpful infinite ammunition).There are also a large array of vehicles available to steal and hijack, from the cheap rusty Tuk-Tuk all the way up to the Chevalier 999. You can also find tanks, fully loaded with unlimited ammo of guns and autocannons, as well as helicopters and planes with the like.Overall, Just Cause 2 is an aesthetically astounding, open world adventure, and Avalanche Studios has done an amazing effort at pulling off a gaming spectacle. If you like a game where one minute you are parachuting out of the sky and next minute you are speeding down the deserted Panauan highway with the cops on your tail, this game is for you. The amount of things to do and see are amazing, and I thoroughly enjoyed this game and will be playing it for a lot more hours to come.

												There really isn't much I need to say about this game. I've sunk hours in on console and on PC, and it is a fantastic open world game. People are going to compare it to Grand Theft Auto, of course, and while in some areas you can, you really can't in others. The map is unbelievably large, and the storyline itself advances through ♥♥♥♥ing up everything you come across in whatever way you deem necessary for it to come down or explode. You can grapple all over the place and you have unlimited parachutes plus the ability to steal ANY vehicle in this game - if it moves, you can steal it. Anything from little bikes up to massive jet liner airplanes.Do I recommend this game? Hell yes. This is the most fun you will ever have in an open world setting. No restrictions, no linear story crap (unless you REALLY want to, and even then it's pretty damn open), just good old fashioned fun.

												Imagine an open world bigger than GTA V's Los Santos. Then picture a man grappling to every building in sight and swooping above people's heads with his parachute, shooting them from above and just generally causing a whole lot of paperwork for the government. That's the basic premise of this game.The goal of Just Cause 2 is to basically cause as much chaos as you can in order to overthrow the government of a small island called Panau. The game has a main story and a whole lot of side missions, but it takes so long to get from one story mission to the next you basically forget what the story's about. But who cares when you can obliterate everything in sight? Certainly not me.If you like large open worlds and Michael Bay-style action, this game is for you.

"DON'T BLAME ME, IT WAS A DESIGN FLAW"What would you like me to say on this intouchable completition of 100%? Jaws down.If I say it's huge, it actually is. You cannot even imagine how huge it is. I've never ever played at a BIGGER game world than Panau is yet. It's so big that Panau contains desert, jungle and snowy mountains. It'll take you at least 10 minutes to jet it over and over 5 hours to walk across the map. While GTA takes you like 2 mins to jet it through, and 2,5 hours to walk it across. Both is confirmed guys, not just random number.Complexity of things you can do here? GTA Series are nothing in comparision with this. There is over 350 towns and villages to explore and liberate, more than 120 military bases to liberate, explore and destroy, those contains big airports, harbors, radar stations and so on. More than 100 cars and planes to drive. More than 2000 items to collect. If you want to reach 100% completition it is almost impossible. You gotta work your♥♥♥♥♥off and you still won't reach that without modding the game because 6 items out of 2000 are missing. I am not blaming devs. You cannot blame them for it.Yes, there is only 7 main missions without relevant story, but 49 faction missions, 50 challenges, 30 bridge limbing and another stuff that will do it. I said that there is no relevant story, because I really feel like it is not. This game is more about destruction of the Panau that those 7 story missions. If you like cruising around with jet, I recommend you to buy Black Aerial DLC for that certain jet, otherwise rest is garbage for me. Multiplayer element has been added recently, I just tried it briefly, but will put out standalone review on it sooner or later.To make it shorter than the game is, you will definitely not make any mistake buying this and certainly not spending week or more inside the game.Bonus Point: Country TransitionRating: 9/10

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												Just Cause 2 brings much needed improvement upon the first game's format. Improving in almost every conceivable way, it turned a game which was riddled with problems and a repetitive nature into an enjoyable experience. It's far from perfect, story falling into the stupid and cliche once more, but at least somewhat satirical this time, if it was meant to be taken seriously then the voice acting certainly didn't help. Just Cause 2 can also crash on systems well above recommended requirements albeit rare. Besides those points, there's a lot to like. The soundtrack is better than ever and perfect for the game. Graphics are great and polished, assuming you can overlook the forced depth of field (developers please stop this.) The world is expansive yet detailed with various areas like mountain regions, cities and deserts to explore and complete. Quality of gameplay as a whole has improved drastically with better controls, intuitive combat including use of grapple, better side activates, missions and creative bosses. Avalanche studios put real effort in between JC1 and 2 and it shows. It's a much more enjoyable game, sure it can be repetitive going for 100%, but I still got a solid 18 hours out of the game without completing it fully. So I recommend picking it up for anyone interested in an open world sandbox all about causing chaos then go for it.

content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												Just Cause 2 pumps you into action the moment the game starts and barely is there time to catch your breath as you go from one area to the next, one plane to the other, one seaboat to another and one parachute to the other. With new enemies, weapons, and vehicles, the game gives you an array of items at your disposal... yeah, well, good or no?The guns are pretty weak as the realism doesn't set in in this game at all, which is expected considering that's just how the game is meant to be, which is pretty great at times. The game does get repetitive somewhat quickly after about a day's worth of gaming. Only 'specialty' areas are unique, though not in large numbers. Enemies remain the same, without much difference in them and aren't memorable. Same characters as in Just Cause but with, of course, Baby Panay and his men and a few others. Vehicles are nice, nothing special (probably intentional), and easter eggs are plenty, though a rather obvious one is one a lot of people know about whether they've played the game or not or have seen what the egg is referencing.So, yeah, weapons are meh-y, vehicles uneventful, enemies boring, and locations repetitive.But does that make it a bad game? NOPE. It's fun, yes, but as the review states here and there, it does get repetitive, but the non-stop action and hilarious ways to kill enemies makes the game quite addictive. Overall, gameplay to 100% completion takes about... well, maybe 80 hours if you play it casually but non-stop probably less. Is it worth doing new games on it? Maybe more-so after a long time of not playing just to be nostalgic.What this game offers over other games of similar style is... well, the style. Infinite parachutes, grappling hook for every occasion, and a kickass Rico makes the game all the more fun. So go ahead and get it, it's fun and addictive but you shouldn't be expecting to want to play it every waking moment after the first few hours.7.5/10

content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												Just Cause 2 is a 3rd person shooter that looks and feels a lot like GTA and Saints Row. It's main trademark is the grappling hook, that can be used to pull yourself to objects far away or pull objects towards you.Pros:+ Vast environment with distances that feel realistic. Driving 10 kilometers feels like driving 10 kilometers in real life. Downside of this is that the world feels a little empty and repetative at times.+ All the major weapon classes are represented and you can upgrade your gear.+ Pretty good story. + Memorable character build and rich dialogues.+ The local propaganda radio reflects on your latest actions, trying to cover everything up.+ Playing a villain was served in a satisfactory, humorous manner, that suited the whole story.Cons:- Missions start to feel repetative very quickly, falling roughly into 3 categories:	1. Go kill everyone and blow everything up in a particular place.	2. Help some gangsters get to a fortified camp and protect them until they take it over.	3. Destroy something/someone in a limited timeframe.- A few bugs like falling through a bridge or not being able to get out of a turned over car.VerdictIt's not amongst my favorite games, far from it. Travelling the distances was a pain and the repetative missions got tiresome quickly. On the other hand, unleashing havok has a quality of it's own and the game surely has a ton of content to keep your hands tied for some 20+ hours.

Posted: February 22, 2014
												1st...I cannot believe this game has been made in 2010-11, and why i never tried it since now...Welcome to Panau! One of the biggest south asian map, ever created for a game of this genre. You are Rico, i like to think he's a Saboteur, as you'll get contracts and missions of all kind to destabilized a whole system of corrupted government by undertaking tons of main and side missions.Guerillas, warfares, infiltration, extraction, black market weapons, vehicules, sabotage, and blowing up everything to gain alliances, or make new enemies will be your everyday life in Just Cause 2!Exploring this vast and huge world the way you want, gives this game a very deep immersion feeling.This is how you'll find new villages, cities and even military bases you'll have to control.To do so, you have a gazillion different horde of weapons, gadgets, and vehicules of all kinds.From sea gliders, to apache style helicopters, tanks and armored vehicules, you want it? you got it! How about modifiying your vehicules? you can! how about a flak gun on a Tuk Tuk? you can!How about controlling your own airport, having your very own private jet? YOU CAN!It's a 100% open sandbox world where you can do almost everything you want, the way you want, when you want.Think of it like if GTA would have been having babies with Battlefied.The vast majority of everything you'll see in this game is 100% destructible, so you can create havoc in villages, destabilize entire supplies of gas and water, expend your territories, you decide who you are working for, and keep what you've earned by helping guerillas groups, rebellions, or even the corrupted gorvernment itself in a "Che Guevara" mood-style storyline.The optimisation for most gaming rigs is also amazing, right now i'm running mostly everything on ultra, and on the benchmark, i get an amazing 120 FPS all the time. No matter what i do in game and the graphics are beautiful, and breathtaking, good job to Avalanche studios!This game has been made for players to enjoy themselves, and have fun!When you can jump from your helicopter, open your chute, casual fly to a nuclear plant, use C4, blow it up, then run away with one of their tank, fight your way through, then call your black market dealer on the spot, to order a boat to get away?....What more do you need?...This is honestly an amazing game in its genre!10 out of 10 for Just Cause 2!

content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Average story, decent voice acting, repetitive and uninteresting missions and yet I can't not recommend this game.Why? Two words: Grappling hook.The fun in this game, primarily, comes from the grappling hook. The grappling hook allows you to quickly traverse terrain, hook on to a vehicle to then hijack it or even use it to tow a vehicle around. You can even jump from vehicle to vehicle and add parachutes to the combo so that you can either hook on to another vehicle or use the momentum from your grappling to parachute higher and further.The open world of this game is set in the fictional island paradise of Panau and a very large paradise at that. The graphics are quite impressive, particularly in the large mountainous areas or high above the world in an aircraft the view really is great. The range of vehicles is large from cars, motorcycles to various aircraft and boats; using these vehicles to explore the world and wreak havoc is incredibly satisfying.That brings me to my next point. The destruction. The explosions. The weaponry. Whether it be a handheld gun or one attached to a vehicle, you're going to be causing a lot of damage to Panau. Causing a lot of explosions is satisfying and (other than grappling hooks) is what this game is all about.I am yet to play the multiplayer mod that was recently released on Steam but multiplayer in a game such as this will only add to the fun and chaos.Just Cause 2 is a game that frequently goes on sale so it wont be hard to find it for a very reasonable price and it's a small fee for hours and hours of fun. Buy now and never regret it.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												Just Cause 2 is all about running around and having fun with loads of toys and things that go boom. If you go into this game thinking you're going to get some seminal epic, you're in for a surprise. Just Cause 2 is a tongue-in-cheek look at espionage video games. This guerilla simulator lets players raise hell in an immense open-world practically any way they want, and the results are sure to bring a smile to your face.Wherever you go, you'll find all sorts of things and people to destroy. Whether spitting death by launching rockets from a helicopter or grapple hooking a hapless enemy to a moving vehicle, you'll want to get creative in the ways you dispatch your foes. As such, this game is filled with hilarious combat most action gamers will really enjoy. Unfortunately, it also comes with its fair share of unpolished bits that the abundant humor simply can't cover up completely.The first 15-30 minutes of Just Cause 2 is a clear example of how not to make a video game. The introduction is filled with lots of things that plague the title throughout. For starters, this is where you'll be introduced to the cliché characters and lowbrow plot; I don't think I've ever cared less about a game's story - something about 'The Agency' hunting down a dangerous American in a nationalistic tropical island rife with pretenders to the throne. Making matters worse, the poor narrative is exacerbated by the loathsome dialogue and painful delivery. Some may argue that the developers tried to make the game cheesy in these regards in order to accentuate the humoristic approach the gameplay takes, but I'm here to squash those claims - the story, characters, and voice acting utterly fail.Thankfully, the run-and-gun action is often exceptionally fun. There are lots of different weapons to use, and delivering death in cruel and unusual ways soon becomes second nature. Perhaps the biggest reason for the off-the-wall combat is the dual grapple hook in Just Cause 2. Imagine romping through 3-D environments with Bionic Commando-like abilities. Now imagine pulling off grapple swings, hitching to vehicles, and zipping to locations that are over a hundred yards away! Moreover, pulling enemies out from behind turrets and immediately riddling them with bullets will not only net you special kills, but is ever so satisfying.The dual grapple hook is also an excellent way to get around combat zones. Rather than simply running from place to place, you'll be better served by zipping from building to building like some kind of mutant monkey. You'll be able to get in and out of combat in a flash, and get yourself into advantageous positions simply by aiming for the building tops. Of course, the grapple hook is only one way to get around. You'll also have access to a parachute that can be engaged on the fly at almost any moment.As good and as game-changing as these gameplay workings are, combat is held back significantly by the poor shooting and cover mechanics. This game essentially does away with any of the technical shooting skills gamers have developed in FPS and TPS titles over the years in favor of a user-friendly, cinematic approach. As long as your gun is pointed in the vicinity of an enemy, you'll turn him into Swiss cheese. While this forgiving tact makes pulling off aerial kills and other stunts a breeze, it also dumbs down the encounters.Another of the game's foibles is the difficulty in getting around the expansive world. As good as zipping around the combat zones can be, getting from one point of an island to another is extremely slow. This is due to a number of factors. First, the vehicles are cumbersome. Driving, flying, and boating around the hilly, overgrown, and obstacle-laden land, seas, and skies of Panau is painful. Second, the world is so big, you'll sometimes go nearly 10 kilometers (6 miles) to get to your next objective. Even in a chopper, this can take upwards of five minutes - in a quad, car, or rickshaw/golf cart you're looking at 20 minutes, minimum!In an attempt to ameliorate this, you can call up a black market dealer and get extracted from your current position to your desired location. While they let you call upon this glorified shuttle service as much as you want (and for free), it only really works if you've already been to the location.Despite the inefficiencies inherent to negotiating a massive open-world, Panau is a great place to get your guerilla on. I liked the varied terrain : encompassing beaches, urban zones, factories, villages, refineries, fortresses, jungles, air strips, mountains, etc. Panau is essentially a warrior's playground. There are literally thousands of nooks and crannies to discover. By exploring the world in detail, you'll get access to weapon and vehicle parts as well as get nifty health boosts.In addition to upgrade chests, you'll also find cash stashes that can be used to purchase new equipment. Cold, hard cash isn't the only form of currency in the game, however; Chaos is every bit as valuable. By taking out government vehicles and emplacements (radio towers, gas tanks, satellite arrays, holding tanks, transformers, etc.) you'll be awarded with ever-increasing Chaos totals. The more Chaos you unleash on Panau, the more faction and agency missions as well as back market items become available.Whether you're playing the game on PC, Xbox 360, or PS3, you'll be treated to a beautiful, if somewhat unrealistic, time. The Southeast Asian archipelago of Panau isn't exactly as lived in or as sensible as I would have liked, but it is a great place to play, nonetheless. If there was one word I had to use to describe Just Cause 2, it would be 'ridiculous'. The game never takes itself seriously, which, for the most part, is a good thing. However, sometimes this lackadaisical approach extends into areas where it shouldn't, resulting in an often unpolished, even amateurish experience. Still, the game has fun in spades, so all who pick it up are likely to have a total blast!

content:
Posted: May 3, 2016
												Now that I've finally gotten around to finishing the main quest of this game, I feel I have enough information to write a review. It is a phenomenal game.While the story is nothing to write home about and the controls can feel a bit wonky at times, the gratification that comes from grappling a jeep to the road and causing it to flip into the air or decimating harbors and army bases with a minigun are simply unmatched among games I've played. This game's main "gimmick" is your grappling hook that spits in the face of physics and basic logic. This 1 inch cord has enough power to hold a car to a helicopter without breaking and defies the concept of momentum, letting you jump off a skyscraper and grapple onto the road below without being harmed. The game also features a respectable arsenal of upgradable weapons and vehicles to terrorize the island nation of Panau with.There are few negatives that I can come up with for this game, but there are some minor issues:When you fall from a tall place, you transition into "falling mode" and controls shift accordingly. The distance it takes to transition seems inconsistent and can result in cheap damage.The DLC seems a bit overdone. I'm not a huge fan of DLC in the first place, and I bought the full version that includes the DLC, but I didn't feel like it added much to the game.The game is actually incomplete. The developers accidentally left out a few of the collectables, making it impossible to 100% the game ingame, you can still get all the Steam achievements though. I'm honestly puzzled as to why the devs haven't fixed this issue, since it should be a really easy fix.Lastly, and this may not be a bad thing for some people, Panau is big. Too big. Allow me to elaborate, I have played this game for 131 hours and I'm only about 75% of the way done. The conquering of towns and military bases is a blast at first and retains its enjoyability well, but I don't see myself 100%ing the game any time soon.Despite these complaints, I've gotten 131 hours of solid enjoyment out of this title and will definitely be playing it more. If this game looks like fun to you and you won't be too bothered by its problems, then this is easily worth its asking price.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												The Just Cause franchise was the reason for my entrance into the gaming world. When I first bought my Xbox 360, I saw that Just Cause 2 came with it; I was intrigued. So, little AraChN1DZzz Unsp0K3N decided to get that, and boy, did he love it to death! He spent over 2 years completing that game on every difficutly. Once he was done, he thought, "Wow, I should get JC1!"But we will talk about JC1 in another review,  thank you summer sale. The actual game Just Cause 2 was a follow-up from the initial development of the character "Rico Rodriguez" from Just Cause 1, voice acting by  Robin Atkin Downes .  In fact, the two games have very similar endings. Baby Panay is supposed to be portrayed as some grotesque man who would kill his own father just to get the "Presidential" role of Panau (This isn't a spoiler, you are told this during the opening scene of JC2).  The graphics/physics In JC2, the graphics are a really big letdown. The scenery of the game is heavily painted, but that may be because of the huge map size, but if you are to compare the graphics to Battlefield, you will see that JC2 didn't really try hard enough in terms of the Graphical side of the battle. Also, you see that the creators basically copied and pasted the "spinny trees" and even buildings just to make the game look big, which really shouldn't be an option. However, I must say that looking out into the distance at some opposite islands really calms the feeling of the game. The physics of JC2 always keep you on the edge of your seat. The unrealistic yet amusing stunt jump always adds the feeling to the game that you are, in fact, playing a destructive game rather than one where you "look...out into the distance" and enjoy the view, you can do that when you complete the game, [reach 100% completion, impossible, right?] The grapple hook in JC2 was majorly upgraded from the usless grapple gun given to you in JC1, which is what the game is all about, the evolution of the grapple hook, as we see in JC3,  with the infinite tethering and the wingsuit.  The AI Being a very experienced player, I know what it is like to have  ♥♥♥♥♥♥  AI in a game, especially in JC2. At times, the AI is completely messed up - if you were to drive on the road in Panau City, the civillian AI would run away screaming "Hey, he got a gun!", which really doesn't make sense. Also, when I decide to inspect a Wilforce Trekstar [Panau Police] I see the passenger soldier standing up, waving his damn hands in the air like his favourite song has come on, on the propaganda news channel! One more criticism is that the usage of the military plane was never really implemented. I get Level 6 Heats, but only UH-33 Chippewas come, rather than a SI-47 Lepoard, which would really spice things up.To summarise, I would say that this game has its ups and downs. To be honest though, the map size was waaay out of its time, but that is what you can expect from pure perfection, except the copying and pasting. But really, this game is magnificent and if you can look past the Graphical exterior, then I know that you will have fun with this game.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												So I bought this game not really knowing what to expect. When it just came out, someone said it was awesome. And I gotta say, I am not dissapointed.The game lacks realism on certain parts of the game, for example the grappling and the infinite parachutes. It is those things that makes the game awesome. It is a bit hard to get used to in the beginning of the game, but once you are used to it, you are glad you have it.This game as a third person shooter is also a succes. Again, a bit difficult to get used to the dualwielding/single wielding hotkeys. The dual wielding is awesome in the middle of fights, because if you use it correctly, you don't run out of ammo most of the time. No game is perfect, neither is this game. The stronghold takeovers are pretty repetitive, there aren't many of them, but all of them are the same: same goals, same order of objectives. The only difference is the difficulty.The missions are mostly unique. I really enjoyed most of them. Some of them take a long time because it is a long mission or because some of them are kinda difficult. The shorter ones are usually pretty easy: Go there, do this and you are done. But there is a nice variety of missions.Overall, if you like third person shooters and or weird games, then I strongly recommend this game. I haven't play multiplayer yet, so I don't know how good that is.

Posted: March 22, 2015
												Do you like GTA? Then you'll like this game as well! Just Cause 2 has less missions than several GTA games, sure, but it delivers way harder in personality and the actual content in the missions themselves, while providing excellent mechanics for an open world game, including more realistic explosions and realistic world response. Having the Panau military hunting you actually feels like you're wanted, and you can have epic car chases without having it feel weird and terribly unrealistic. Above all, it supports several ingame cheat codes, which imo is a must of open world singleplayer games, since when the content is overwith, you can screw around with your game. That's absolutely fantastic! There's also a multiplayer mode in which you can play online, but unfortunately not many plays it properly, and Panau is a huge, huge open world area, so it's not funny for the most part, I'm afraid. The game on it's own though, I can only recommend it!

content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												A beautiful sandbox game about overthrowing the Government of Panau on a quest to find out the true reason and purpose of why you were sent to assassinate the man who thought you everything you know (Being a badass wize)Gameplay:Your given all you’ll need (not as 1st but as you progress) to start enjoying yourself as you rip about Military establishments and resources in efforts to gain “Chaos points” that contribute to progressing the story (It’s to simulated how far you throw the Island in anarchy [but sadly the islands citizens are to poor/lazy to even show their world is going to hell no matter how far you progress)]Driving in this game feels great except for the few situations where you’re driving a vehicle on a terrain is shouldn’t be driving on but don’t worry, the game gives you a set of “Agency Vehicles” that should be able to hand the rough island of Panau better than the citizens “budget cars”Flying is a little less great compare to driving mostly due to the lack of speed control and your plane relationship to water. Helicopters on the other hand is almost the polar opposite of the problem, since you their control way of taking off and landing and having the ability to take your time dealing damage with them instead of worrying of crashing when swopping. Ground controls may be tedious at times (when dealing with climbing mountains) but the grappling hook ability combined with the parachute makes it fairly easy to get where you want after taking some times to keen your skills on the controlsVisuals: In my opinion even in today time, this game is one of the best looking games on PC. The world is set on a tropically island and during the day you get the full range of vivid colors of the jungle of Panau while during the night you get a overtone of blue with the specs of light in the world shinning over the water. There also rain weather that happens randomly throughout the game but I’m not sure if there is a “Blizzard” variant. The games looks its best at the twilight and dawn hours of the day where you can see the sunset in all its glory attempting to reach over the horizon as it slowly descents into night .Story: The mainstory line is ok (nothing to special about it) but the Factions missions are pretty much a ongoing joke compare to it. Mostly the missions are used to make you participate in events full of all the crazy♥♥♥♥♥shit the devs thought of for you. Sometimes the mission isn’t that interesting along the faction timeline but there are a few jems that makes it worth it to play through all the factions missions regardless of how you feel about the morality of each of them.DLC: Some of the DLC in the game is truly unnecessary, I’m just going to give you a list of what not to get and you can determine wheatear or you want the restDO NOT GET: Bull Eye’s Sniper (Less damage Sniper riffle with the return of faster firing and more ammo, it takes 2 heashots to kill the Commando type enemies)Rico Signature gun (Pretty much a fully upgrade revolver fun at 1st, useless latter when you realized what I did)Maybe: Black market Boom pack (Never found myself to have much used for these weapons ingame but if you’re planning for online multiplayer I think these weapons will serve you much better there)What made me loss my motive to complete the game to 75% (for achivement purposes) is not the time I had on me in this moment of time, its that I just lost intrest after I finish all the faction missions + Agency missions were complete and the game turn into bassically into a Find n' seek blow them up. I might go back to finish it tho one day...

Posted: November 21, 2014
												Just Cause 2, from what I've played, is one of the best takes on the one-vs-many concept - put an entire island country in front of a near demigod of a man, and put the results into code. In essence, it is an action movie turned into a game, and in the best way I've seen in my years. Irreprievably overpowered gadgets, an open world large enough to keep you constantly on the run, driving vehicles, flying vehicles, standing on top of vehicles, standing on top of flying vehicles, and a goal at hand: to free the oppressed people of a small, fictional island from the tyranny of their dictator.Thinking about buying this game? Keep this in mind: You will never feel much satisfaction quite like leaping from an exploding building into a full-on skydive.Good luck, soldier.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												So I bought this game not really knowing what to expect. When it just came out, someone said it was awesome. And I gotta say, I am not dissapointed.The game lacks realism on certain parts of the game, for example the grappling and the infinite parachutes. It is those things that makes the game awesome. It is a bit hard to get used to in the beginning of the game, but once you are used to it, you are glad you have it.This game as a third person shooter is also a succes. Again, a bit difficult to get used to the dualwielding/single wielding hotkeys. The dual wielding is awesome in the middle of fights, because if you use it correctly, you don't run out of ammo most of the time. No game is perfect, neither is this game. The stronghold takeovers are pretty repetitive, there aren't many of them, but all of them are the same: same goals, same order of objectives. The only difference is the difficulty.The missions are mostly unique. I really enjoyed most of them. Some of them take a long time because it is a long mission or because some of them are kinda difficult. The shorter ones are usually pretty easy: Go there, do this and you are done. But there is a nice variety of missions.Overall, if you like third person shooters and or weird games, then I strongly recommend this game. I haven't play multiplayer yet, so I don't know how good that is.

												Buy this game and play it.  That's pretty well all that needs to be said but I'll say a bit more.The grappling hook in this game may be one of the single best/fun mechanics I've ever played with in a game.  Hooking vehicles, boats, planes and more together is just plain fun.  Using it while also shooting down some rag tag militia might be even more fun.  You get a fair share of vehicles and weapons to wreck mayhem everywhere.  There's also a lot of missions and story that keep you interested in causing more mayhem.  As well you get a gigantic island with lots of variety to the terrian and good deal of towns/cities to play in and cause further mayhem.With all that mayhem you cause you may generate a fair amount of attention from the local authorities, but thats okay, cause using your grappling hook to get out of those situations is just as fun as when you used your grappling hook to get into the situation.Get this game and enjoy the hell out of it like everyone else has.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2013
												Multiplayer is fun, you should experience it... If you havent been following the development of jc2 mp, it can house up to 9000 players on a single server.. granted the hardware and bandwidth is there.I have been playing on a single server with around 1000 active players at once. Interaction with other players with a 1000 connected has some noticable lag, but not horrible. I should also note that the server I was on is located in the UK, while im based in the US, distance is one of the biggest factors determining lag.its a ton of fun.Although there are no real objectives in mp, you can figure out how to have a blast in very little time.The mod also features Race and Demolition Derby modes that you can hop into at anytime. Race is a lot of fun, you will find yourself racing dogged old busses, or super fast performance cars, 4 wheeler atvs, even base jump racing !Go to one of the local attractions like /tp airport ... and watch the utter chaos as a few hundred people spawn vehicles and weapons and have an all out free for all.I should note that the Multiplayer mod is still in beta, so there are occasional crashes, but nothing to get squeemish about, the game itself is really well optimized for PC, and holds up well... until you start doing crazy physics stuff like flying a boat thats spinning at 100rpm :D ( Yep I said Flying a boat ! )Its madness, its halarious, its goofy, and its fun.Single player is sandbox action and comedy wrapped into a nice package.Not as in depth storyline as GTA4, basically go here destroy that, go there rescue him type of idiom.

Posted: March 8, 2015
												The Just Cause 2 story is that of one in a porno. It is necessary to have a story, but it doesn't mean it is a good one. Quite frankly this is one of the worst stories I have ever had the enjoyment of playing. BUT story doesn't mean♥♥♥♥♥♥in this game and you can tell. This game is about doing whatever you want because JUST CAUSE. Wanna strap a vehicle to a Passenger plane and watch physics break down? Do you want to give the middle finger to physics and logic? Do you wish to play a sandbox with a little more? Well I sure as hell do. My word is this game something special. Without the Grapple Hook this game would be nothing special. But hey you have a Grapple Hook which kicks the Hook Shot's♥♥♥♥♥ With this ungodly tool you become the most versatile being in the game. Think of this like Spiderman, but you don't cry like a little ♥♥♥♥♥. You can cling to walls and shoot "webs" and swing around not giving a single ♥♥♥♥. On a more serious note I love driving around the map taking in the magnificence of Panau Island and it is easily one of the more rewarding factors in the game. You'll discover over 350+ locations in which you can watch burn as you cause untolds amount of choas and havoc. Something else worth metioning is the mods. The mods are easy to work and are all hilarious. Some make you a god other add to the games graphics. Needless to say without mods the game is still fine on its own. Mods only exist to "spice" things up in the Just Cause Universe. Oh yeah there's multiplayer. I would wait on the Multiplayer until you have played around in Singleplayer. Multiplayer is Singleplayer but with way more players (No♥♥♥♥♥♥:\). In conclusion this game is the near perfection of large scale sandbox with plenty of hilarious moments and some seriously addicting gmaeplay. Remember each timke you play will never ever be like your last session.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												There are HOURS of fun to be had in this game. I dare you to 100% it. The extensive open world map has impressivly fluid graphics. It consists of smaller areas such as military bases, large airports, cities, and small villages that can be 100% completed if you collect all boxes scattered within and destroy obviously marked structures (water towers, fuel towers, power stations, gas lines, etc.) though this attracts attention. This progress leaves you with upgrades and cash that can be spent on helocopter drops including weapons and vehicles. Once a place is descovered you can fast travel to it from your map.Of coures there is an arsenal of fun weapons (that can be expanded with DLC) though an FPS this is NOT. The weapons combat has a more arcade feel and there is apparently no such thing as stealth. Tuck yourself away with a sniper rifle to pick off the bad guys and you'll find one shot and everyones guns are instantly fireing at you. There's also no real reward for killing them. In the end you will find yourself almost always having to evade their infinte numbers and waiting for the cooldown before walking back in front of them like a different guy on the island in the same outfit as the guy just shooting them.The grapple and parachute make traversing the map extremely fun and easy. The grapple also serves a melee attack and can string together two objects including vehicles, humans, and unmovable serfaces. aah, good times. As mentioned in another review this would have been amazing to see in Farcry 3. As far as the story it's more or less just there to move you around the island for yet another mission and to unlock challanges. The story doesn't do much to deepen your experients with the game so don't expect The Last of Us story line action movie style. The misions and challenges are still fun and do well for breaking things up with different types of action. I don't want too sound too negative in my review but i won't gush over it either like another greatest game ever. However, I would highly recomend this game to any PC gamer (especially if you can get a deal) if only for the kicks and giggles. If it was missing something before it was multiplayer. But as of the date of this review the multiplayer mod DLC was released on Steam. Happy Gaming.

Posted: February 14, 2014
												This isn't a game; this is more of an "interesting out-of-context things generator" in the sense that Just Cause 2 is pretty much a wreck-it-up where you play as secret agent and gravity fugitive Rico Rodriguez who has to do things on the island of Panau. What, exactly, do you do on Panau?Destroy stuff.That's literally the goal of the game; you destroy stuff and it advances the plot. The game gives quite a few creative ways to do it; you can take a motorbike, drive fast, and parachute off of it as it goes flying into a gas station, causing everything to explode as the cops are suddenly after you. The cops seem rather intelligent... somewhat. Gameplay's pretty solid, and in general the entire game feels like an open-world action movie. Panau is colossal and has a ton of things to do and destroy. This game does have a few bugs and glitches, however, but it doesn't take too much away from the game.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												In this action packed game, you are in an agency to find Baby Panay. He is the president of the island, Panau, on which you play on. Do mini quests for people and build up heat by destroying Panau army supplies and whatnot. Even gas stations! Download mods at justcause2modding.com and play to your hearts content with that new tank you've been wanting! After you complete the game, you go into mercenary mode which you can go freestyle and have fun. Plus, the percentages in mercenary mode tell you how complete you are from pretty much doing everything. Use your grappling hook, parachute, shotgun, or even rocketlauncher, to earn chaos. This is the game (from what I've heard that it's much like Grand Theft Auto) that you would not want to miss out on the sales for!

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												There is nothing more to say about this game as it’s pretty much like a Dolph Lundgren or Michael Dudikoff action movie. One man against the world. In this particular case, against a dictator on a little oil-rich fictional island and different groups of interest who wanna stage a coup and take over. Of course a communist fraction is not missing ;-) This game is all about action, action and action. Don’t expect a deep meaningful story, its pretty much like this kind of movies. I don’t wanna spoil so some missions feel like being on top of a rushing train and killing a hundred of enemies. Even though the lack of a profound story, Just Cause 2 is quite entertaining in my opinion. The graphic looks good, different flora and fauna on the island plus you can destroy a lot of things. Also the achievement system is reasonable. The only negative aspects about the game are recurring missions alongside the main story, no animals and that the citizens are doing nothing at all. Anyway I had my fun. Especially after work where I had no intention to use my brain rather than just play and kick♥♥♥♥♥ My rate: 7/10.

												A sandbox crime game, of sorts where it was made to mess around in. 2 1-handed firearms (dual wielded, discourage the same weapons), 1 2-handed firearm, grenades and explosive, a grappling hook which is used as a melee weapon and infinite parachutes in a massive open world.The story, dialog & characters are so bad it seems like a satire; still you want to barf at some dialogs though.No skyboxes per say: what you see, you can go to. content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												Just Cause 2 is an open - world game. There are 3 factions, which gives you different missions and dialogue. The 3 factions are: The Reapers, The Ular Boys, and The Roaches. You also have your main missions, which lead you to the ending (if it wasn't self - explanitory). But that isn't what makes the game super fun. You have a huge country to explore: Panau. After quite awhile, you unlock a bunch of badass equipment, vehicles, and even have an extraction helicopter that can bring you to places you already discovered. You can fly a plane from one corner of the world, to the opposite end of the world. There are boats, helicopters, ATV's, motorcycles, etc. And, how could I forget, the grappling hook. The grappling hook is used to do all kinds of things. When you skydive, if you plan your grappling hook properly, you can break your fall! You can latch on the enemies and pull them to you! Anyways, that's all I can explain. But this game's a blast. You should buy it; full price or not! JUST BUY IT! Final Verdict: 9.5/10.

Posted: January 8, 2014
												This is just one very great game. The controls are fluent and feel really nice. The missions are a bit repetitive apart from the story missions, which make up less than 20% of the game. You have to complete minor missions before you can progress in the story line. However, you only need a handful of minor missions to unlock all the story missions. That's the one major flaw in this game, it doesn't push you to do a lot of minor missions, you can rush through the story line is less than 15 hours. After that, there is a HUGE amount of sidemissions and collectibles to keep you busy. Not as much fun as the story but still well worth your time. The graphics are very nice, especially considering this game is a couple of years old already. Goes around on steam for less than 10 bucks, this one is a no-brainer for anyone loving shooting, action and an open world to explore.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												Just Cause 2 is a unique game which implements many features that no other game - at the time of release or now - has ever implemented. Somewhat enjoyable, gameplay offers an extensive amount of amusement, when you get the hang of it that is. Jumping around with your grappling hook and parachuting from tree to tree to avoid gunfire is just one of the many aspects of this game that makes it notable. Storyline is thin and will be finished quite promptly and unfortunately, once you've gotten to that point, it just loses its fun-valueThe repetitiveness of the missions, atrocious voice acting, and overall lack of effort that seems to have been put into just about everything except fun game mechanics can leave a stale taste in one’s mouth. Flying around causing aimless chaos is fun for a few hours, but when you realize that's the only entertaining element the game has to offer you get bored quickly.

												It has an infinitely usable zipline.Other than that, it's an action movie in game form. Filled with gunfights and explosions, you play as an American secret agent/black ops who goes and tears up a Southeast Asian dictatorship.This comes in the form of an open-world(the map is huge) 3rd person shooter with: campaign missions; mini-missions done for revolutionary groups and mafias with simple escort, collect, hijack, destroy, and kill objects; races; military bases and cities with infastructure to destroy, leaders to kill, and upgrades to collect; sprinkled around the map.Combat isn't too challenging, as you soak up any damage you can get. Posted: February 14, 2014
												This isn't a game; this is more of an "interesting out-of-context things generator" in the sense that Just Cause 2 is pretty much a wreck-it-up where you play as secret agent and gravity fugitive Rico Rodriguez who has to do things on the island of Panau. What, exactly, do you do on Panau?Destroy stuff.That's literally the goal of the game; you destroy stuff and it advances the plot. The game gives quite a few creative ways to do it; you can take a motorbike, drive fast, and parachute off of it as it goes flying into a gas station, causing everything to explode as the cops are suddenly after you. The cops seem rather intelligent... somewhat. Gameplay's pretty solid, and in general the entire game feels like an open-world action movie. Panau is colossal and has a ton of things to do and destroy. This game does have a few bugs and glitches, however, but it doesn't take too much away from the game.

Posted: March 8, 2015
												The Just Cause 2 story is that of one in a porno. It is necessary to have a story, but it doesn't mean it is a good one. Quite frankly this is one of the worst stories I have ever had the enjoyment of playing. BUT story doesn't mean♥♥♥♥♥♥in this game and you can tell. This game is about doing whatever you want because JUST CAUSE. Wanna strap a vehicle to a Passenger plane and watch physics break down? Do you want to give the middle finger to physics and logic? Do you wish to play a sandbox with a little more? Well I sure as hell do. My word is this game something special. Without the Grapple Hook this game would be nothing special. But hey you have a Grapple Hook which kicks the Hook Shot's♥♥♥♥♥ With this ungodly tool you become the most versatile being in the game. Think of this like Spiderman, but you don't cry like a little ♥♥♥♥♥. You can cling to walls and shoot "webs" and swing around not giving a single ♥♥♥♥. On a more serious note I love driving around the map taking in the magnificence of Panau Island and it is easily one of the more rewarding factors in the game. You'll discover over 350+ locations in which you can watch burn as you cause untolds amount of choas and havoc. Something else worth metioning is the mods. The mods are easy to work and are all hilarious. Some make you a god other add to the games graphics. Needless to say without mods the game is still fine on its own. Mods only exist to "spice" things up in the Just Cause Universe. Oh yeah there's multiplayer. I would wait on the Multiplayer until you have played around in Singleplayer. Multiplayer is Singleplayer but with way more players (No♥♥♥♥♥♥:\). In conclusion this game is the near perfection of large scale sandbox with plenty of hilarious moments and some seriously addicting gmaeplay. Remember each timke you play will never ever be like your last session.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Just Cause 2 is that special kind of game that comes around once and a while. You see it for sale, think "this looks quite silly, might give it 10 minutes." 3 years later you are still rolling around laughing when you drive a motorbike into a helicopter and grapple onto another one. Full of all the insane action hero madness you will ever need, but instead of watching steven segal doing the action, you get to! with a multitude of vehicles and weapons to go and terrorise the government of panau island. And when i say island, I mean a full island. Massive and varied landscapes ranging from snowy mountains to cities to airports. If insane action hero madness gets a bit repetative with the same weapons and vehicles, Just Cause 2 has you covered with DLC! From Monster trucks for ploughing down streets to a giant gun that shoots out air, DLC is varied and gives more hours of fun. "But Official_joeliecus, I only enjoy games where I can meet a stranger and blow his face off with a shotgun" you say to me through a screen... somehow... Well, someone else has got you covered with that. Just Cause 2 Multiplayer Mod! Take those years of gameplay and spend more years of gameplay with someone else of whom has given years of their life to fun. Go and have a cargo plane race. Go and crash cars into each other, Twisted metal style. Go and ramp off of your friends boat in a boat, jump out and shoot him in the testicles, or overies (not sexist). This is the game you want to go to when you tell your friend "wouldn't it be cool if they made a game where..." and this game probably has it. Except dating simulation. It doesn't have that. To make a long review short, Just Cause 2 is one of my most recommended games, ever, and i've played skyrim... It is worth every milli-penny. Trust me.

Posted: February 14, 2014
												When picking up this game, I didn't expect to sink so many hours into it. Essentially, the game is a summer blockbuster movie with more explosions than a Micheal Bay film after he drank a nitroglycerin cocktail with a dash of oil for flavour. Although the story, dialogue and voice acting are entirely terrible, I feel that this is a deliberate move by the developers in order to create the impression that it is your everyday blockbuster action movie with atrocious story in video game form. However, I think you could probably tell that part from the fact you sent a 4 by 4 truck covered in C4 explosives hurtling into a military base that seems to have a particular need for massive tankers filled with petrol in highly exposed and vulnerable areas and leap out, materializing yet another one of Rico Rodriguez's seemly endless parachutes from what appears to be the aether, and glide over as tanks of petrol, oil pipelines, telecommunication dishs, radars and towers made from corrugated iron all explode in a massive fireball about as bright as the sun whilst you pick off any remaining survivors with a gatling gun that you ripped off a turret point, as well as annihilate an attack helicopter piloted by a particularly angry government soldier. So yes, I recommend Just Cause 2.
